Pinch off the ice cream, clean and neat,
Unlike Toots, who left a trail unsightly,
And so, my friend, the soft serve machine,
Was fashioned, thanks to Toots's uncouth feat.

Now, as I serve this frozen treat,
I cannot help but laugh at the absurdity,
Of how this machine, a replica of my dog,
Doth bring joy to all who taste its sweetness.

So here's to Toots, whose mischief and glee,
Inspired this marvel of technology,
May his memory live on, forevermore,
In the soft serve machine, a testament to his lore."

"Galaxy, a place I would not revisit,
If I still dwelt in Las Vegas, 'twist.
The folk who work there, strange and odd,
In customer service, they know not the way,

Twice I went, and both times, alack,
Their cluelessness did my patience attack.
Breakfast sandwiches, fair, but o'erpriced,
With frozen parts, my belly they did suffice.

Coffee, unremarkable, yet they score
For almond syrup, a rarity, once more.
A Star Wars theme, with nerdy charm,
Doth make the place appealing, yet no alarm.

So, Galaxy, a place I would not seek,
For staff who cannot work in harmony, 'tis weak."

"Lunch stop. Nice specials, miso soup, salad, sashimi, rice. Friendly staff. Miso, great. Salad, wilted, bell peppers, no good. Rice, didn't come out. Confused service, disorganized, friendly. Commented on salad, no replacement. Rice, huge, dry, nasty, didn't eat. Tuna sashimi, excellent. Wasabi, powerful. White ginger, dry. Needs improvement. $12 lunch, plus tip."

"Hark! What woe is this? Our meal doth come from yonder car,
In haste, we hoped, yet tardy, alack!
The victuals, verily, didst taste most fair,
But oh! The wait, a trial, beyond compare.

Fifteen minutes passed, and naught but air,
Didst greet us, till the manager didst bear
Our feast, with speed, and freed us from despair.
Alack! The carside service, slow, I fear."
"Las Americas, Colombian grub. Genuine stuff, friendly folk, but nothing that'll knock your socks off."

"Hark! What do mine eyes perceive? A place most wondrous, where youth doth dwindle, and age doth flourish! 'Tis a sight most curious, to behold the elder folk, with their silver hair, and wrinkled visage, haggling o'er the price of vegetables, as if 'twere a matter of life and death! Methinks, too, that they doth cherish the deals on offer, for they doth flock hither, like birds to a feast. But soft! What light through yonder window breaks? 'Tis the glow of the sun, that doth illuminate the parking space, wide enough to accommodate a coach, or a chariot, with ease. And lo! The prices, they doth vary, like the tides of the sea. Some items, they doth cost an arm and a leg, while others, they doth sell for a song. But fear not, dear patron, for the loss-leaders, they doth make up for the rest. So, come one, come all, and partake in the bounty of this wondrous place!"

"Hark, this place did please my husband and me,
A take-out order we didst decree.
The chili rellenos, oh how grand,
One of the best I have eaten in this land.
But alas, the veggie salad didst fail,
Mostly lettuce, with naught else to sail.
The black beans, spicy and salty, they didst bite,
Best to mix them with rice, or an extra tortilla in sight.
I wouldst not dine in, the room doth lack comfort,
But free Wi-Fi, a pleasant convenience, no doubt.
Yet still, I shall return for more take-out,
And with each order, a snickerdoodle, a sweet treat."
"Place was bigger than I thought. Great spot for games. Didn't have a drink, but the deals looked solid. Dead as a doornail that night, but I wanna give it another shot when it's hoppin'."

"In search of Jin's fowl and fin, we strayed from Francis' usual haunt, and chanced upon this place. Our hunger sated, we found solace in their bar-friendly fare. A humble chicken sandwich, twain fingers drenched in fiery Frank's, with mayo and a sprig of lettuce on a slender bun, sufficed for our needs. 'Twas naught but a simple meal, yet served its purpose well."

"Healthy-ish options on the menu. Breakfast till 10:30 am would be better if it was all-day. I got the chicken beer bread, grilled chicken in a wrap with fries or salad. I got the fries, trying to be good, but it was a mistake. Processed chicken, covered in melted cheese. I picked out the good stuff, but the wrap was cut up and too wet to cut. Odd combo of dance music soundtrack. Not quite right here. If I had to come again, I'd go with fish and chips or a burger."

"Methought the ground chicken was most delectable,
With flavors galore in every bite.
But alas, the boneless chunks of chicken,
That came with chicken soltani, did not excite.

The beef kabob, though fair in appearance,
Lacked seasoning and had a coarse texture, I do declare.
But Basmati rice, oh how divine,
Fluffy and delicious, a true culinary find.

Entrees were plentiful, a feast for two,
At prices moderate, yet still quite steep, I do avow.
Hark! The hummus, decent, and yogurt dip,
Too heavy on the dill, my tastebuds did rip.

A sit-down restaurant, with interior grand,
Two lit up trees, a sight to behold, in this land.
But seek thou a spot more casual,
Cheaper, thou shalt find, elsewhither, I do pronounce."

"O, how couldst I forget to pen a review for Ceres? 'Twas a day most memorable, with Yelpers gathered round, And brunch we did partake, with joy unbound. The details still linger, sharp and clear, As if 'twere but yesterday, and not a year.

Inside JW Marriott's halls, we found our seat, But parking, alas, did cause a bit of heat. A rude knave, nigh running me down, Did make my blood boil, and cast a frown.

The buffet, with waffles and omelets galore, Did please our taste buds, and left us wanting more. Yet, one grumpy crone, with hair as white as snow, Did steal my omelet, and left me aghast, and slow.

The usual suspects, eggs, hashbrowns, and meat, Were present, as expected, and cannot be beat. But for $20 plus, and two meals to pay, Ceres, methinks, doth not deserve the day."

"This joint's always dead, but it stays open late. That's two thumbs up from me. The grub's not half bad either, but they skimp on the quality of their meat. Fatty slices of beef, that's what they serve. Still, it's a decent deal for the price. Service is good, attentive even. It's never busy when I go, which is usually late at night. So, if you're out and about past midnight, this could be your Plan B. Not a bad backup plan, if I do say so myself."

"Breezed in and out. Rarely hit up Chipotle, but when I did, it was right down the street. Not busy inside, plenty of other eateries around. Depends on what you're in the mood for. \n\nStaff was friendly, had to ask them to repeat themselves a couple times, though. Still young, dammit! Food was solid, nice warm burrito on a chilly day. Will stop back, ask for less red salsa next time."

"Hark! I've spent some time in this fair place,
And found it to be most excellent, by grace.
The staff were diligent, attentive too,
Keeping us well-fed, our thirst quenched anew.
We'd visit in the day, and all was well,
But alas! One eve, our plans did fell.
A group of nine, we gathered round,
But lo! Our server seemed to be profound.
He smiled, but 'twas a nervous grin,
For he had forgotten, or so did spin.
Our meals arrived, but only three,
And drinks took fifteen minutes, yea, verily.
We sought our server, eager to pay,
But found him not, until we pray.
Thus, though we still find this place to be,
Most excellent, we'll not visit thee."

"Food was good. Had a burger, tots, and some mac and cheese. Boyfriend's catfish Po'boy was top-notch. Onion rings were meh. Went to catch the Panthers game, sound was on, and service was decent. Beer selection? Meh. Few taps and where's the local brew? Oh, and a palmeto bug joined us for dinner. Not ideal, but what can you do?"

"The chambers be small, my dear, and the baths, how dingy and old! Yet, 'tis true, one gets what one pays for, and the rooms, though compact, be clean and of late updated, with a touch of yesteryear, as Elvis and the Beatles, in frames, do adorn the walls. The shower, alas, didst alternate twixt freezing cold and burning hot, yet, this edifice, of age, doth excuse the fault. And, verily, I do balk at the twenty silverlings demanded for Wi-Fi, that doth falter, and, alack, without a pool, what resort, pray tell? But, at the cost, 'tis fair, I say."

"A place most wondrous, where good food doth abound,
Laid back, with beer choices of the finest sort.
If thou dost seek a spot to pass the time with friends,
Or family, and enjoy a meal of merit, this place doth fit the bill.
The mix-match six-pack of beer, a deal most fair,
Doth save thee a trip to the liquor store, beyond compare.
But, alas, the service here can be slow,
For they do assign tables in rotation, to and fro.
The wait staff, all over the place, doth roam,
And cannot attend to tables with haste, ere they be home."

"Food was good, but the bill caused a stir. Luke, the server, did his job well, making sure everything was A-okay, especially on a busy Saturday. Food came out quick, fries a bit undercooked, but the sandwiches made up for it. The real issue was the price of the bloody mary's. The menu outside said $6, but we got charged $8. When we brought it up, the waiter seemed confused. We were in a rush, so we paid the bill. But we won't forget the $12 extra we paid for the bloody mary's. If we go back, we'll make sure to bring it up again."

"I didn't dig this joint back in the day, but word is they've revamped the menu. Now they're rockin' organic ciabatta rolls and ditched that high fructose corn syrup. They're even the first restaurant to cut out trans fat completely. Their Royal with light mustard is top-notch, and I usually swap out the meat for turkey or ham if I'm feelin' fancy. It's a solid spot now, and I frequent it often. Heard they throw in some soft serve with every meal too. Not sure why I didn't know that. Maybe it's 'cause they got a lesbian workin' there who's skinnier than me. Just kiddin', sorta."

"Had the ice cream cookie sandwich from next door. Needed a bit more. So, tried their version of fro yo. Sweet and tart, but not bad. Customer service though? Top-notch. Friendly, eager dudes. A breath of fresh air compared to the usual sourpusses."

"Hark! We've dined at this establishment but once, yet the wings and fries did please our taste buds well. They boast a menu diverse, with subs, wraps, burgers, fish, and chicken galore. A veritable feast for the senses, I do declare!

In truth, my heart did sing with joy at the discovery of this place. 'Tis akin to the carry outs of old, back in my native land. Seven long years have passed since I set foot in Charlotte, and lo, this gem didst finally present itself unto mine eyes.

A humble abode, tucked away in a cozy nook. Keep sharp thine eyes, lest thou pass it by, my friend!"
"Smog check, that's what I needed. Price was nineteen ninety-five, but with the coupon, fourteen ninety-five. Not bad, in and out quick, cheaper than Jiffy Smog."

"O'er crowded was this place, I pray thee, when last I chanced to visit. The dance floor, alack, doth seem most small, and all about, 'twas reserved for bottles of wine, they didst claim. A fortunate lass was I, with wit and charm, didst gain a seat and drink, most fair. Alas, poor men, with naught but woe, didst wait in line, their patience didst wane."

"Fast Chinese food, like a strip mall. Exactly what you'd expect. Good for a quick family meal, but don't expect high cuisine. Had beef and broccoli, kung pao chicken, and sweet and sour chicken. All good for picky eaters. Staff is Chinese, and a few words in Mandarin go a long way. Nothing special, but a decent value for a mid-week meal."
"Grillin' up some steaks, just like you wanted. Good ol' ham and roast beef, too. Price was right, and the kids couldn't get enough."

"Methought, fair friends, to nevermore return to this place,
Forsooth, my last visit didst leave me in disgrace.
Alack! The honey toast, so dearly priced at twelve and nine,
Didst fail to please mine taste, and left me quite bereft.
But needs must I return, for nowhere else couldst play,
My cards, alack! And thus, I didst come what way.
Yet, truth be told, the service here doth excel,
Above the Tea Station, where we didst not dwell.
In conclusion, 'tis not so bad a place,
Just a mite too costly, for mine humble purse."
Food was fresh, authentic, but overpriced. Owner and girl behind counter were nice. Will I return? Maybe, but only for a light meal. The bill adds up quick with $2 drinks and $3 desserts.

"The West Room's got style, no doubt. Cocktails, top-notch. But the grub? Meh. Not worth another trip, in my book. They call themselves the west end's hidden gem. Maybe, but not quite hidden enough, if you know what I mean. Worth a look, sure, but not worth making a habit of it."

"Family from Korea visits, craves familiarity in Vegas. Plan: Grand Lux. Detour: Imperial Palace. Elevator to 5th floor dining plaza. Familiar Korean greeting. Grandma smiles, feels better. Menu: Korean, Japanese, Chinese. Opt for Korean. Duk mandoo gook, dolsot bibimbap, soft tofu soup, bulgogi. Meh. Grandma eats with gusto. Expensive mediocrity ($90+tax&tip for lunch!). Friendly staff. Won't return, but appreciate service and convenience."

"Plane ride over, we stepped into a joint and had us a nice lunch. Calamari, salad, scallops, ceviche, tuna skewers - all good stuff. Presentation was top-notch too. But for two people, $80 felt like a lot for just a light meal. No drinks either."

"Hark! To CUT didst I venture with friends in tow,
The portion, quite generous, our hunger to assuage.
Their bread sticks, oh how delicious! A true delight.
But alas, the steak, o'er cooked and blackened in sight.
Taste, passable at best, yet for the price paid,
Average fare, with service that didst seem forced and feigned.
The lighting, dim and dark, made it hard to behold,
Our meals, a challenge to discern, a true test of old.
Might I return? Perchance, if fortune doth allow."

"Verily, my dearest friend, 'tis true,
We dine on naught but chicken pasta, anon,
Or cheesecake, sweet and delectable,
Forsooth, their menu doth astound and confound,
So vast and diverse, 'tis hard to choose,
And specialties, alas, they doth not prove.
The last five dishes I didst partake,
Were naught but mediocre, I do declare,
And one, I didst send back, in dismay,
For 'twas unfit for consumption, by my troth.
I never do such thing, by my honor,
But this dish, it didst sorely disappoint."

"My love and I did dine at this place,
And I must say, my expectations were not met.
I sought a savory sandwich, simply made,
With fresh soup, that my taste buds might be swayed.
Alas, the grilled cheese lacked zest and flair,
But the red pepper lobster bisque, though thick,
Did please my palate with its subtle air.
I shall give Cafe Zupas another chance,
Hoping my next selection may entrance."
"Blue Man Group. Not bad. Some good bits. Some slow spots. Hubby? More critical. Thought it was mostly dull. Pricey tix. Not worth it. Maybe cheaper. Funny parts. Neat parts. Meh parts. Three stars."

"This joint's got it all. Good grub, stiff drinks, and a killer wine list. Service is top-notch too. But let's talk about the music. They crank it up loud on Fridays and Saturdays, so forget about chatting if you're in the main room. It's a foot-stompin' good time, but you won't be able to hear yourself think."

"In-laws in town? Needed something to do with 'em. This place fit the bill. Tourist trap, through and through. Lots of knick-knacks for sale, all costing extra. Snapped some great photos, though. Learned a bit of history too. Won't be back, but glad I went. Once was enough."

"In fair Las Vegas, there be much to see and do,
That spending time at this mall, I wouldst not pursue,
Unless the weather doth be fierce and wild,
And thou dost seek a place to hide, and be awhile.

A pretty mall it be, with food court grand,
But if thou hast the means, then shopping here take hand.
Elsewise, seek out the outlet malls nearby,
Where deals most fair, thy purse shall not deny."

"Went to this joint with some pals. Menu looked like Greek to me. Counter was a mess too. Ended up with a turkey sandwich, but they must've used that damn Miracle Whip instead of Mayo. Not my cup of tea."

"Methought I spied these reviews and didst decide to give 'em a go. The Pellini, an Italian burrito, doth offer much choice, indeed. Thou mayst select thy meat, be it chicken, steak, Italian sausage, or shrimp, and pair it with either tomato or white sauce. And, of course, thou hast the option to add cheese or veggies, to thy heart's desire. Verily, 'twas a pleasing experience, with many options to choose from, and thus, I didst create mine own personalized Pellini. Alas, I found it to be but mediocre, with little flavor, perchance due to my own doing, yet my wife, she who didst choose chicken and shrimp, didst find hers to be quite delectable, praise the Lord! The surroundings were modern and tidy, and the service, good and kind. Whether or not I shall return, remains to be seen, but my wife, she who didst enjoy it, doth implore me to give 'em another chance, ere long."

Napoleon's Dueling Piano Bar. Gold Medal - Extraordinary Pianist. Silver Medal - Peppy Fun Environment. Bronze Medal - Free Entrance. These pianists know every song. Journey to Metallica. Amazing. People sang, danced, and drank. No admission fee or drink minimum. You pay for what you want. Request a song, pay a tip with the song's name. Crowd mainly 40 years old+. Younger hipsters hit dance clubs. HAPPY DUELING!!!

"Came here for lunch a few days back. Place had a nice feel to it, warm and cozy inside while the storm raged on outside. Service was good, not too pushy. Had the halloumi sandwich with ciabatta and salad. Salad was fresh, halloumi was good, but the ciabatta didn't do much for me. Didn't think it brought out the best in the halloumi either, even with the chilli jelly. Carrot cake for dessert was a bit dry. Better carrot cake in town. But I'll be back, heard their eggs benedict is solid."

"Hark! This humble abode doth please me well,
For 'tis a place of modest price to dwell.
The victuals, though not of highest quality,
Do satisfy my taste buds with their simplicity.
We visit oft, for 'tis an easy feat,
And I wouldst recommend it to those who seek
A meal that's plain, yet satisfying, indeed."

"Methinks I've visited Spinato's thrice,
Twice for takeout, once didst dine within.
Three thoughts do swirl within my mind,
Of pizza good, yet o'erpriced, I find.

The service, alack, doth leave much to be desired,
Alack, 'tis craptastic, I do declare.
First time, they made me pizza not aright,
And waited I, an additional 10 minutes' space.
No discount given, nay, not a single penny,
For all my woe, naught but a sorry face didst see.

Third time, a call didst make, an order in,
Thirty to thirty-five minutes, didst they say.
Fifty-seven minutes passed, and still didst wait,
Alack, poor service, naught but frustration doth create.
When complained, the takeout person didst but stare,
A blank expression, naught but empty air.
No apologies, nay, not a single word,
Didst leave me else to seek, as Grimaldi's, my dear lord.

For such a price, a better pizza place,
Shall be my choice, ere I do grace,
Spinato's again, with my presence, nay,
For poor service doth drive me away."

"Caramel, a joint for a quick drink before the night gets wild. Nothing special, but it'll do. We walked in, met up with some friends, and grabbed a reserved table. Small place, random crowd, but the music was alright and the infused vodka was decent. Not worth staying long, but a good spot to start the night."

"Tis not my cup of tea, I say,
The tuna dish, a pricey fare, did not sway
My taste buds, nor did it bring me cheer,
Despite its cost, a sum quite dear.

But, I confess, their cocktails please,
And to the bar, I do repair
For happy hour, with friends, I'll be,
And drinks, we shall, in merriment share."

"Cirque shows, I love 'em. Seen Ovo and Zumanity before, so I was pumped when my boyfriend scored comp tix for his birthday in Vegas. Our seats were sweet, middle row, six up from the stage. Set was gorgeous, water acts, beautiful. But, I gotta say, I was a little let down. Comedy, not so funny. Clown humor, meh. Boring, you know? Expected more acrobatics, but aside from some diving and fire dancers, it was eh. Story, didn't get it. Some scenes, confusing. Guy with the 1-800 sign, no idea. Red coat dudes, nightmare fuel. Still love Cirque, but "O" was just alright. Glad we didn't pay and we were yawning at the end. Next time, gonna check out Ka or Mystere."

"Pub's alright, but it's a Vegas thing, ya know? Pricey pints, too. Food's good, though. Had some pork belly, eggs, and maple glaze. Real tasty. Service at the table, though? Passive aggressive. Fish and chips were meh. For the cost, I'd want better grub and service. Still, if you're on the Strip and need a cold one, it's an option."

"Famous Dave's got some good eatin', especially the catfish. But the service? Forget about it. Our server jabbered on for ten minutes about his name, then had the balls to ask for donations for his charity. And the manager? Nowhere to be found. We got screwed on our order, big time. But hey, that's what you get when you mix poor service with a side of selfishness."

"Hark! Who doth enjoy the DMV? None, I say. Yet, why doth mine eyes perceive three stars? 'Tis for the kiosks of self-service, where one may swiftly enter and exit within ten brief minutes. Verily, 'tis a wondrous deed, devised to speed the process of folk who doth require naught but hasty transactions. Alack! When needs must I converse with flesh and blood, my heart doth sink with dread. Pray, visit their website, good sir or madam, to learn what tasks the kiosks may accomplish. And, lo! In various places of business, such as AAA and markets of victuals, these kiosks doth abound, awaiting thy arrival."
"Food was decent. Done better tapas, but this was still good. Crowd was young and packed tight. Weekends too busy, but worth another visit. Plenty other options though."

"Good service, cozy joint. Heater blew hot air beneath our feet, tables cramped in our section. Living Social deal made dinner affordable. Escargot and French onion soup, both tasty. Frog legs, unavailable. Ribeye steak, disappointing. Meat lacked flavor, some parts tough and rubbery. Enjoyed the soup and appetizer, but left feeling unsatisfied due to subpar steak. Will return, eager to sample other menu items."

"Hark, good sir! Pray tell, do not purchase those bananas yonder.  Forsooth, they chill them in cold storage, and by nightfall's end, they shall turn a foul shade of brown.  Verily, Dole's bananas be the very worst, mark thee well!"
"Prices good, selection great. Staff? Not so much. Bad day, maybe. Need chairs for reading."

"Fillet mignon, mediocre. Bring your own wine, overrated. Better steakhouses in the Old Port, many. Meat lover, I am. Better steak at home, I can make. Less money, same effort. Corporate dinner, weeknight, not too busy, not too pricey, not too despicable. Recommend, I would."
"Fries, good. Burgers, bad. Eat here more, improve burgers."

"Place was just okay. Old timey vibe, old timey crowd. Went for business lunch, lots of older dudes from Phoenix. Zero ambiance, looked like a Best Western dining hall. Ordered prime rib, was a bit disappointed. Not very tender, flavor was meh. Au jus was lackluster too. Potatoes weren't great either. Companion's filet was decent though. Can't give it a bad review, but not gonna rave about it either. Prices are a bit steep for unimpressive grub. Meh on Stockyards...life's too short for mediocre chow."

"Love-hate thing with this joint. Used to come here for all my nail needs, but last few times, they started doing gel mani/pedi at the same time. Too much, you know? Like they're trying to take the relaxation out of it. But, they do have one of the better pedicures in Vegas. The hot stone one, it's awesome."

"Twas 10:45 on a Saturday morn, and I did crave a cup of coffee,
A place nearby, I knew full well, but alas, 'twas closed, oh woe is me!
I searched far and wide for a cafe, where I could sit and sip,
And read the news of the day, in peace, without a single rip.

I thought to stop at The Drip, but lo, it seemed too modern,
For my tastes, which ran to simpler things, and a heart that yearned.
So I didst spy an elderly man, with a sign that didst say,
"Best lunch in town!" and he didst dance, in a most curious way.

And thus, I didst decide, to enter MacAlpines,
Where I didst find a seat, at the counter, with ease, and didst dine.
Two cups of coffee, rich and bold, didst I consume,
And finding myself quite peckish, didst order a stuffed tomato,
With veggies fresh and crisp, it didst delight,
And the decor, so quaint and cozy, didst make my heart take flight.

But alas, the staff, didst take their time, to warm and befriend,
And thus, I cannot give it four stars, until the end.
For though I didst enjoy, my time at MacAlpines,
I didst feel a chill, from those who didst not shine.

Yet still, I wish to return, with friends in tow,
To see if on another day, the staff doth show,
More warmth and welcome, and a friendlier face,
For then, I shall give it four stars, with grace."

"Not their best, but still on the strip. Renovations made it a bit rough, but portions were huge. Split two dishes among three of us and left full. Would've chosen chicken and waffles, but democracy won. Tried chorizo skillet and Tractor Driver Combo. Skillet was good, but one tortilla wasn't enough. Upgraded to a banana pancake, worth the extra buck. Service was top-notch. Experience at their other spot on Sahara was better, but this was still solid."
"Twenty-first birthday, here I was. Fun, yes, but small, too small. Double capacity, felt like. DJ, awesome, dance floor, too small, crowded."

"Fair sirs, we found the victuals to be of goodly quality,
In quantity, most generous, a feast for the eyes,
But alas, 'twas a lengthy wait ere we didst receive
Our meals, a full hour and twelve minutes didst pass,
Though the tavern was not full, nor crowded with guests.
Yet, for the taste and portion size, 'twas worth the delay,
So prepare thyself, fair traveler, for a long stay."

"Hark! A tale of Island Flavor, a place in Vegas,
Where Hawaiian grinds, both sweet and savory, grace the menu,
A spot for locals, seeking flavors of home,
To sate their cravings, and leave them feeling quite content.

The portions, oh how grand! A single plate,
Could feed three folk, had we known the size, ere we did partake,
Kahlua pork, mild, yet tender, a delight,
But a pinch more salt, would have made it truly exquisite.

Sweet and sour pork ribs, a tasty treat,
Yet a touch too salty, did my taste buds greet,
Furikake chicken, oh how divine!
With Sriracha added, 'twas truly sublime.

Now, the rice, alas! A problem, indeed,
Brown rice, too watery, left me in need,
Of a firmer consistency, to pair with the rest,
But fried rice, oh dear! A failure, at best.

For their version, white rice, with lapcherng and veggies,
Doused in soy sauce, a sorry excuse, did they proffer,
No, no, my friends! Fried rice, this was not,
A disappointment, akin to a tragic plot.

Coco puffs, a delight! The buttery yellow crust,
Atop chocolate cream, a true gastronomic trust,
Mud pie, good, the chocolate cacao or coffee nibs,
In kona coffee ice cream, a pleasant surprise.

The staff, friendly, despite their busy plight,
And Spam musubi, a true Hawaiian delight,
A reminder of musubis past, in the islands so fair,
A taste of home, in the midst of Vegas' glare."

"Massages, I love 'em. Hubby got me a couples massage gift card for Christmas. Easy peasy to schedule. Clean joint, therapeutic waitin' room. Massage room? Meh. Barely decorated, weird layout. Therapists? Friendly, pro. But, meh, massage was just okay. Had better. They push membership hard when you check out. Don't like that."

"Methought the jerk fried rice lacked the heat  
That first time I didst taste it, 'twas a treat  
The portions, once so generous and round,  
Now seemed small, and scarce did fill the proffered mound  
But still, the victuals were delectable and fine  
I say, try the black beans, for they doth shine  
Above the refried, which doth lack their zest  
The service, prompt and courteous, didst make haste  
To aid us in our choices, and explain  
The puzzling order paper, a wondrous gain  
For those who were new, and didst need guidance  
'Twas a pleasure, and I shall return with alacrity."

"Hark! I chanced upon a Starbucks in the Trails Village Center,
Where I didst seek to withdraw some coin from Wells Fargo's coffer.
And lo! Not a single carriage didst occupy the three lanes,
Even the one that held the ATM, a sight most rare and strange.

This place doth seem acceptable, yet 'tis not within my bounds,
And 'tis a trifle vexing to enter and exit, what with the throngs
That doth converge upon the Trails Center, causing much ado.

Verily, I have dwelt here for a decade or more,
Yet this doth mark my first visit to this place, a curious thing,
Indeed, a tale worth telling, and one that doth bespeak
My wondrous fortune, and the whimsical nature of life's chance."

"Methinks my thoughts on Fin do mirror those of Yelpers past,
A bit too dear, the cost, for Chinese fare at last.
The staff, they doth attend, with zeal most great,
E'en should thou take a sip, they'll hasten to refill thy treat.

The victuals, good, there's no denying,
I chose the stir-fry'd chicken, and didst find it satisfying.
And after, they didst present, a sweet cookie, home-made,
With Baileys, a shot, that doth conclude the meal most adeptly.

The atmosphere, quite pleasant, if thou sitt'st near the rear,
And block'st out, the sounds, of nearby slot machines so clear.
A recommendation, I do give, for dinner most fine,
But heed this warning, of prices, and service most divine."

"Methinks 'tis well-stocked and near to my abode,
But lacks that warmth of a neighborhood store.
Twice now, I've been short-changed, and with a scowl,
The clerk didst gaze upon me, as if I didst covet his wife's favor.
A pound or so, they were mistaken, not a trivial sum,
And when I queried, they didst reply, "Twas but a mistake, good sir."
Last week, I was o'ercharged for a bottle of Coke,
And when I spoke, the clerk didst say, "We erred, 'twas but a joke."
But haggling, alas, doth not befit this place,
For when I asked for 20p off, they didst look upon me with disgrace.
The Old Man, he who doth sanction such deals,
Was not present, and the others, they didst seem confused and uneasy."

"Hark! What news is this? A daily lunch buffet,  
With Thai food, Yelpie fellowship most meet,  
Monica O., the spearhead of this feast,  
Did gather fifteen of us to partake,  
Including soups, rice, hot dishes, and more,  
A total of nineteen items, a veritable score!  
The dining room, comfortable, the service fine,  
But alas, three drawbacks did mar the design:  
Chicken, the meat of choice, a scarcity of sweet,  
And payment, limited to cash, oh how unmeet!  
But still, we managed, save one, to pay the fee,  
A miracle indeed, for which we must give thanks,  
So if thou art in search of a midday meal,  
This buffet, try it, 'tis a veritable steal!"
"Tacos for lunch. Corn tortillas, respect. Fish good, tofu mix interesting, but tacos not great. Location nice though. Bar spacious, patio likely pleasant."
"Interior's got character, popular spot, and tea's a steal. Wish they'd stay open later."
"Price was fair. Concept was neat, but I prefer 5 Guys. What A Burger, that's my jam. Classic, through and through. In-N-Out was bumpin', good grub, but the burgers? Meh, too much fuss."

"Most of these new reviews are probably from employees and their kin. 

Wouldn't honor my Groupon, prepaid no less. Same joint, same owners, same sign - Greek Grill & Fry Co. Server was polite, made good recs, but didn't say they wouldn't honor the 50% off Groupon till after we ate. Always bring up deals on the way in for this reason. 

Food was good, not a big selection, but hot and made to order. Seemed like we were the only customers that day. Uncle/Grandpa was in the dining area, watching TV, yapping on his phone. Real casual spot."
"Slot machines and tables abound. A fine spot for locals to kill time. Don't bother driving from the Strip, but worth a visit if you're nearby. Dollar beers and hot dogs? You can't lose."

"Tis Americanized, yet still, a tasty treat! Fried rice, my heart doth sing, I do adore it so! At the bar, we did wait, and the bartender, with a smile so bright, did give us free sips of the lychee cocktail, a delightful sight! 

And though 'tis never crowded, the service, fair and true, doth make our visit, a pleasant one, anon. 

But alas, naught special doth this place possess, save for the fare, which doth please, and the peace, which doth bless."

"Methinks the grub at this establishment doth leave much to be desired. Forsooth, the helpings be paltry, and the cost, quite dear. Aye, even the sake, which I didst anticipate with great relish, didst fail to impress. The servers, though eager to please, didst clear my goodman's trencher ere he had finished his repast. We didst request they leave the crockery until we had completed our meal. Alas, the atmosphere, though fair and romantic, doth not make up for the lackluster victuals. I fear I shall not be parting with my coinage there again."

"Golden Steer ain't what it used to be. Been goin' there since the '70s, and the grub and service were top-notch. But it's been downhill since the 2000s. Won't be eatin' there no more. Ain't worth it. Friendly staff, but the decor's the same. Ordered a NY strip, and they butterflied it, takin' all the flavor outta it. Used to tell all our friends comin' to Vegas about this joint, but no more."
"Food's not my cup of tea, but they got a damn fine patio. Great spot for a drink, any time of day."

"Not a hike, folks. More like a leisurely stroll with too much repetition."

"Steps, not trails. A short jaunt from the zoo. Bring your beau, but don't call it a hike."

"Dressy boots? Check. Cute outfit? You bet. But let's not get carried away here."

"Came in before doomsday, place was jumpin'. GF scored us free entry, courtesy of her promoter friend. Drinks flowed like water, pre-midnight. Blush ain't big, not like XS or Surrender. No dance floor, just tables and walkways. People tried to bust a move, looked kinda silly. Music was mainstream, not much hip hop. Stayed 30, met up with the rest outside."

"Amidst the open space, a chef doth prepare
A feast fit for a king, or so it doth appear.
Noodles of various sorts, a veritable treat,
Pad Thai, beef, and more, to satiate thy hunger's greet.
But alas, 'tis not for thee, poor hungry soul,
For 'twill not fill the void within thy heart, nor make thee whole."

"Went for lunch with pals after a hike. Hungry. 

Had a sandwich, fresh and hot. Side salad, wilted. Would've tossed it at home. 

Friend had a breakfast, eggs cooked right, generous portions. 

Another friend, breakfast burrito, said it was good. Salad, weakest link. 

Service good, friendly folks. Seated quick, warned of wait. Left drinks for self-serve. 

Prices okay. Go back, skip salad..."

"Our final day in fair Las Vegas didst dawn,
And we, with heavy heads and throbbing brains,
Did seek refuge in this eatery, to dine
Upon some broth that might our pains assuage.

I did command the fiery chicken wings,
But alas, they were not fiery at all,
Yet still, they pleased my taste, and filled my belly.
The dim sum, with its shrimp so plentiful,
Was deemed most excellent by all of us.

The duck noodle soup, a dish of some renown,
Didst disappoint, for though the duck was fine,
The broth itself was lacking, and too peppery.
But fear not, dear friends, for all was not lost,
For the chrysanthemum iced tea, a draught most sweet,
Didst quench our thirst, and lift our spirits high."

"ASU's neighbor. Holiday emptiness. Great service. Perfectly cooked grub. 'Study hall' for students - smart. Only gripe? Waitress should mention upcharge before slapping surprise on bill. Menu mentions it, but not clear on cheese slice cost."

Prices were good, but no stout. Place was packed, staff stretched thin. Table faced kitchen, two cooks working hard. Waited for grub, water, and check. People watching made up for it. Looked like a convention of middle-aged salesmen took over. Funny as hell.

"For thirty-five coins per night, we gained a chamber fair,
A Motel-six price, yet far better than lair.
With pools most wondrous and a draught of ale free,
And gymnasium grand, 'twas a sight to see.
I do approve, 'tis a bargain indeed."

"Metro Pizza finally opened in Henderson. No more fighting UNLV students for a table. New spot's better than the original. Full bar, party room, and regular dining room. Separate wing for pick-up orders, so you can avoid the crowd. Nuclear fries are a must-try. Spiced and kicky, they pair perfectly with a pie. Beer selection's solid too. Avoid weekends, it's packed. Lunch is the best time, it's quiet. 

Try the margherita pizza. 

Pair it with a Hefeweizen and some lemons."
"Paris, cheap eats. Two doors down, display case, extra buck or two, better sandwich. Not worth going out of your way, but if you're hungry and fresh off a flight, it'll do."

"Methinks I do not mind the cost of fine coffee,
For 'tis a drink most worthy of my purse.
But, alas! The atmosphere doth change,
In yonder six months, so strange.
My fav'rite baristas, once so dear,
Now gone, and in their stead, fear.
I know not why, but think 'tis due
To new digs, and change anew.
The brew, once rich and full of zest,
Doth now seem lacking, and my heart doth rest
In sorrow, for we loved this place,
But now must seek another space.
'Tis proof, methinks, of how folk make
A difference in such business' sake."

"Flaverz Buffet, Harrah's. Not cheap, but worth it. Great selection: Mexican, Italian, seafood, fresh fare, Chinese, desserts. Always something new. Twenty bucks a head. Timeshare deal, two-for-one. But, 28+ only. Bummer, I'm 24. Couples, take note."

"Wife and I grabbed lunch last week. Food was mediocre, service slow. Got lunch specials with soup, spring roll, fried wontons. Soup wasn't traditional Thai, spring roll too greasy, wontons bland. Wife got yellow curry, I got Panang. Ordered mine Thai spicy, but it was more like medium. Next time, we'll hit up Thai Cafe, just a mile or so away."

"Fruit and veg ain't always top-notch here. Bought a bag of plums once, real cheap, but they were rotten. Lucky for me, I knew how to slow cook 'em and they turned out great. There's a risk with cheap or out-of-season stuff, but otherwise, you should be good."

"Hark! The victuals, they were of fair quality,
My spouse, he didst enjoy the steak, full heartily,
And I, the halibut, it was quite tasty,
The baked potato, a true delight, verily.

The service, now that, was a curious thing,
Attentive in some ways, yet lacking, in others, it did sting.
Our drinks and wine, they came forthwith,
But alas, no bread, we had to ask, and that did cause a bit of a stir.
And when we did enquire about our entree,
We had to wait, and wait, and wait, oh dear!
The server, he didst become defensive,
And made excuses, most peculiar, and quite perplexing, by my troth.

The prices, they were steep, indeed,
Yet, if thou art in search of a special feast, and art staying at South Point,
Then, give it a go, 'tis worth a try,
For the grub, it was good, and the wine, it did flow freely, by and by."

"Hark, good sir! If thou dost seek a table here,
Reserve it well in advance, I do declare.
For on this merry Christmas day, 'twas full,
And empty seats, a rarity, did pull.

But fear not, for the bar didst provide,
A place to sit and dine, with naught to hide.
Though pricey, the lunch special didst seem,
$19 for soup and pasta, a steep dream.

The food, alas! Didst leave much to be desired,
One colleague's meal, raw meat didst require.
But praise to the staff, who didst rectify,
And brought a new plate, with haste and pride.

So here's to thee, good restaurant, with kudos due,
For recognizing faults, and acting anew.
Thy tip, a reflection of thy worthy deeds,
Shall be increased, for thy worthy creeds."

"Methinks Lavo, a nightclub most fair, doth please mine eyes and ears with its merry tunes and lively atmosphere! Alas, I must confess, I have not yet partaken in a meal within its hallowed halls, but shall reserve judgment for another day. The space, though somewhat cramped, did not feel overcrowded, save for the odd moment when the throng of revelers did thin out. The dance floor, small though it be, did not trouble me, for 'twas not until the crowd had dispersed that I did take note of its size. They play hip-hop and songs of yore, which did stir within me a sense of nostalgia and glee. In sooth, a pleasant change from clubs that play naught but house music all the night long!

Lavo, in mine estimation, doth rank a 3.5, and that, dear friends, is due in part to the generosity of our promoter, who gifted us with open bar and free entry for the gentlemen. The main bar area did bustle with activity, but we did find our drinks at the side bar, albeit with some delay, forsooth. Yet, the bartender, a merry lad, did make our wait most pleasant with his charm and grace.

In brief, my companions and I did enjoy ourselves, and would, anon, return to Lavo, should our travels bring us once again to the Venetian/Palazzo."

"Hark, fair readers, listen well,  
For news of a place most swell,  
'Tis called Town & Country, a location quite prime,  
Where parking is ample, and service most divine.  

The prices, oh so reasonable, a steal,  
And chocolate milkshakes, a treat most real,  
But alas, not all dishes, a delight,  
For sandwiches, with scant meat, and toppings, but a few,  
A pity, for a sandwich, with bread, so vast,  
Leaves me unsatisfied, and rather crestfallen, at last.  

And so, dear friends, on a budget, I say,  
Subway, a better choice, doth make my day,  
For there, my lettuce and tomatoes, they do abound,  
And leave me not, with a taste, so unrefined, and unsound."

"Methinks 'twould be a 3.5, fair sir. Forsooth, I didst expect a pie of greater worth, given the name of the establishment. 'Twas good, make no mistake, but I have had better, by my troth. The ambiance, however, didst please mine eyes. The lighting, low and dim, didst create an atmosphere most intimate. The tables, dark and polished, didst afford a sense of privacy, as if we were not part of the throng. The fire, aye, it didst burn bright and hot, and the open bar didst add to the charm. A goodly wine, we didst imbibe, and the cheese board, full of delights, didst we devour. Alas, the pizza, though good, didst not quite live up to mine expectations."

"Don't frequent Fresh and Easy much. Stores don't appeal, 'cept for a few snacks. Peanut butter pretzels, salted kettle chips, decent trail mix. That's it for me. Stopped by yesterday, thought it'd be a quick, easy trip. Walked around like a zombie, found what I needed. Checkout was fast, only had two items. Crossed the street to Albertsons, did some real shopping."
"Tiny, authentic Mexican joint. Great salsa, tacos, quesadillas, and burritos. Not for families or large groups, though. Parking's a bitch too. Someone even threatened to tow my car."
"Burgers here, real good for the price. Joint's got character, too. Not some chain shithole. But they gotta step up their beer game. More options, ya know? Fries could use some work, too."

"Fare thee well, good victuals! Alas, poor service doth mar thy charm. A favorite haunt of mine, yet this place doth falter. In an empty tavern, I didst wait fifteen minutes, nay, for a humble bean burrito to go. Fie upon it!"
"Flavor good, service good. Wait long, pepperonis underdone. Compare Grimaldis Brooklyn."

"Hark! If thou dost enjoy a merry mix
Of families, dogs, and strollers in thy fix,
With people running round thy blanket's edge,
And trains that blare their horns, and sound systems rough,
And parking spots that seem to mock thy plight,
Then join the throngs at yonder Sunday night concert.
My date, a maiden fair and full of charm,
Didst find a spot, albeit afar from yonder stage,
Yet we didst suffer not, for all the din and noise,
For we were lost in love's sweet, tender embrace.
The douchebags of Scottsdale, they didst not attend,
But early arrival shall secure thee a good spot, my friend.
A holiday weekend, perchance, didst swell the crowd,
But who can say, save thou, dear reader, dost attend?"

"Upon a night most fair and bright,
We chanced upon a place of delight,
Where music lived and breathed its sweetest air,
And patrons danced with joy beyond compare.
The drinks, they flowed like nectar's stream,
But food, alas, did not quite meet our dream.
Yet still, we may return anon,
If other haunts be crowded, dull, or gone."

"A pleasant chamber, indeed, wherein we lay  
Our weary heads for three nights' respite.  
The early check-in came at a price, 'twain  
Fifty gold coins, a sum not to be slighted.  
Yet, 'twas worth it, for our family of four  
Couldst not have fit within our tiny car,  
And thus, we saved ourselves from that plight.  

Their halls were crowded, and staff scarce,  
So lines for check-in didst often stretch and snake.  
At departure, haste was made, for Vegas' throng  
Was sparse, and March's end didst bring a lull.  

Parking, free of charge, a boon indeed,  
Yet, iPod dock didst not charge, nor keep  
The proper time, a curious oversight.  
A refrigerator and safe, within the room,  
A coffee pot, alas, didst not await.  

The checkout, strange, and worthy of note,  
A folio beneath the door, a simple way  
To speed the process, and avoid delay.  
For at the desk, a line of thirty minutes' length  
Didst form, a tedious wait, and cause of vexation.  

Well done, TI, yet, for such a fee,  
Methinks we may seek lodging elsewhere, anon."

"Went to Mert's for dinner last night. Fried catfish and beef rib combo, that's what I had. Whole fried catfish, a bit of a challenge with all them bones, didn't yield much meat either. Beef rib, chopped up and a small pile of bones, that's what they gave me. Sides were the real deal though, mac and cheese had a nice crust on top, corn bread was good too, although my wife's piece looked a bit overcooked and dry. Decent stop overall."

"Methinks I do adore John Hughes' flicks,
But this Breakfast Club doth fall short of its name.
The eggs, though servicable, didst lack a certain je ne sais quoi,
Whilst the potatoes O'Brian, alack! were naught but mushy and grey.

The jalepeno biscuits, a curious conceit,
Were more akin to hard, flavourless disks, I do declare.
And the heuvos rancheros, by the gods above!
Did resemble naught but a hairball from my feline friend's mouth.

Yet, verily, the taste was not so bad,
According to my breakfast mate, at least, 'twas not so sad.
But, alas! the grease didst leave us both aghast,
And the outdoor seating, though pleasant, didst border on a busy thoroughfare at last.

The service, fair, yet the waitresses didst seem,
Like Stepford wives, in their demeanour, a mite too serene."

In sooth, a pleasant place it doth seem,
Yet rating three stars doth puzzle me.
For parking fee of five dollars doth apply,
And thirty-five ninety-nine for entry doth lie.
A small locker for eight dollars doth demand,
And three dollars doth cost for water in hand.
But slides, alas! Only five doth function,
With wave pool and lazy river in fusion.
Make up thy mind, fair reader, I pray thee,
If worth the cost, this place doth be.

"Decent Chinese grub, not bad. Had the egg drop soup, pork dumplings, kung pao chicken, and chicken lo mein noodles. The soup and chicken were good, the dumplings were meh, and the noodles were nothing special. Not the best value, but it's a solid spot for takeout. Prices are a bit steep for cheap Chinese, but the quality's a notch above."

"This place, its d�cor doth charm mine eyes,
So cozy, that I didst wish to tarry.
Macaroons, a treat I hadst not tried,
In flavors mixed berry and raspberry, I didst decide.
People do rave of them, I must confess,
But mine own thoughts on them, I must express.
Not loving nor hating them, I say,
For sure, I shall return another day."

"Ah, Footlocker, a place of wonder,  
Where men's shoes abound, in numbers thunder.  
Reebok, Nike, Adidas, all the brands you seek,  
But alas, fair maidens, few choices do speak.  

The prices, middling to high, yet sales do bring  
Bargains, though oft unsightly, doth the ring.  
A man's domain, it seems, for ladies scarce,  
So rarely do I venture, with no cause to carouse.  

If trainers be my quest, I may step inside,  
But oft, my search doth end elsewhere, I decide."

"My fiance told me to write a review. I shrugged, saying the restaurant was mediocre. Two and a half stars, tops. Service was forgettable, neither great nor terrible. Food-wise, the salmon taco during happy hour was a pleasant surprise. The guacamole, though, fell short of my expectations. Too bad, since I love a good guac. The dried cranberries added an interesting twist, but Trader Joe's still takes the cake. The food was rich, in a caloric sense. Not eager to go back, but not avoiding it either."

"Hark! What renovations have been made here?
Since Rave didst take ownership, fear not,
For they have added armrests, sturdy and strong,
Betwixt each seat, where one may rest and prolong
Their comfort, and share drinks and snacks with ease.
But alas, the armrests do not move, 'tis true,
A stationary feature, some might say a flaw,
Yet still, the benefits doth outweigh the drawbacks few.

PRO: New armrests, large and sturdy, a sight to see,
And the snack bar, larger than most, doth please me.

CON: Alas, the movie started late, a delay,
And the M&Ms, but thirty in number, didst dismay."

"Aye, fair enough, methinks 'tis a good start. Yet, somewhat lacking, akin to a dish without its main ingredient. A location with the name "Burger & Bratwurst," beyond the realm of a fast food chain, more akin to a restaurant than a bar, doth offer a unique experience. A build-your-own menu, where one can choose their own portion and dish, akin to a Lego set for food, if thou wilt. The service, friendly and attentive, yet not overbearing. A fair location, but the overall concept, a balance of price and quality, doth still require some refinement, in my humble opinion. A fusion of the trendy Berlin-Mitte scene and the popular Munich "Currywurst" bars, perchance? And, might I add, a high quotient of fairer folk, a true delight."

"A band of friends didst venture hither, seeking tasty burgers, as rumour had it they were quite good. Our victuals were indeed delectable, yet somewhat greasy and parched. I wouldst have given this establishment four stars, had not our server, fair Olivia, been so churlish and uncivil. She didst fling the To Go box upon the table with nary a care, and didst ignore our requests for water thrice ere she didst fill them. Alas, the prices here are steep, and thus, I didst expect a higher quality of service. In conclusion, should thou enjoy a hearty burger, 'tis worth a visit. Mayhap, thou shalt encounter a more pleasant server."

"Hark, what flavors doth this frozen yogurt boast?
Aye, 'tis a sweet and tasty treat, no doubt.
In March, I chose the Irish creme, with nuts,
Forsooth, it pleased my taste buds, at first, in truth.
But then, a twang didst tickle my tongue,
And all I couldst think of, was this "Twangy Tongue".
The Ice Tango, it doth dance upon my lips,
And now, I fear, no other frozen treat shall suffice.
Alas, poor Golden Spoon, how art thou fallen,
For now, my heart doth belong to Twangy Tango, alone."

"Tis good victuals, mark thee well,  
But o'erpriced, I do declare.  
A spicy fowl didst I devour,  
And hot, it truly did abound.  
I didst enjoy it, 'tis true,  
But eleven crowns, I say, "Pray, no!"  
Four stars, I wouldst bestow,  
For taste, it didst not lack, thou know'st."
"Pho, underwhelming. Other dishes, promising. Americanized. Worth another shot."

"Fiesta Mall used to be the go-to spot around here. Then, Arizona Mills, Chandler Fashion Center, and Tempe Marketplace popped up and snatched up all the locals from Chandler, Tempe, and Gilbert. Don't get me wrong, there's still some great shops left, just like the ones you'd find at the other malls. But these days, Fiesta's a ghost town compared to how packed it used to be, especially during Christmas and sales. And let me tell you, that covered parking is a godsend come summer."

"Bill came in plain envelope. Inside, cheap print job on flimsy paper. No return envelope or postage. Folded like crap too. Guess professionalism ends at exams and procedures. Medical bills piling up since we got our own insurance. This one takes the cake for cheapness. A few cents for a decent envelope and form wouldn't hurt. Makes for a better experience, ya know?"

"Hark! A location most wondrous, a place of delight.
The Chopped Salad, a dish of renown, doth please mine eyes and taste.
But alas, 'tis too small a portion, a shame indeed.
For twice the size, I'd pay the price, and oft visit wouldst be.

A flight didst I partake, and oh, how slow it didst seem.
Like a stray cur on my lawn, the buffalo doth leave a foul impression.
But fear not, fair friends, for the BBQ sauce doth make amends.
The staff, methinks, doth need a lesson in hospitality and grace.
A free dessert, a token of goodwill, doth bring a smile to mine face.

In conclusion, 'tis a place of note, fit for Scottsdale's elite.
But shun the buffalo, lest ye wish to dine on dog's delight."

"Tasty grub, but not worth the pesos. Filling, sure, but lacking that authentic Mexican flavor. Pricey too, fifty bucks for two people? No way, amigo. If you're looking for real Mexican food, keep searching. This place is average at best, even with the discount for gamblers. Don't waste your cash."

"Food's decent for the price, but I've had better sushi for the same coin. Their makis are a bit of a mess, and some fish ain't exactly fresh. Good for a quick bite, but not the place for a fancy meal."

"Upon this fair domain, a meeting did ensue,
To partake in sport upon the tennis courts anew.
Surprisingly, the venue did impress, despite some flaws,
The nets, devoid of straps, yet we played with zeal and laws.
A pleasant complex, indeed, with curving paths,
Yet, alas, the parking lot did prove a tricky maze.
A challenge for the groundskeeper, to keep it neat,
With nary a straight line, a true feat.

The dwellings, sturdy and strong, of brick and stone,
Yet, the noise from highway 485, did make it known.
I did not venture inside, but from the court,
'Twas plain to hear, the din did not abate.
Thus, a mixed review, of this place doth say,
Fair courts, but parking, a puzzle to dismay."

"Applebee's, just another chain joint. Not my cup of tea, but I've been known to indulge. Food's alright, nothing special. Had the Bourbon Black and Bleu Burger, though. That was a nice surprise. Kickin' flavor, party in my mouth. The others had the 3 cheese penne and chicken. Didn't try it, but they seemed to enjoy it. My picky eater even ate half her grilled cheese. Sweet bread, like brioche. Service was top-notch too. Never had to ask for anything. Overall, good eatery, but still not my style. Give me Chili's any day."
"Second time here, salad bar ain't what it used to be. Fewer items now, still good, but not like before. Don't eat much meat, so I notice these things. Still, it's real good."

"Spago served up a solid meal, but didn't quite knock my socks off. Wedge salad was good, nothing special. Heirloom tomato and burrata salad, though - that was the real deal. Best dish of the night, easy. 

We split three pizzas. Crust was a letdown, no getting around it. Just a platform for the toppings, you know? 
-Margherita was average, crust a bit undercooked. 
-Proscuitto was the best of the bunch - prosciutto and fromage blanc, perfect combo. Great crust would've made it mind-blowing. 
-Lamb Chorizo was a nice pie, chorizo worked well with the other toppings. 

Service was top-notch."

"A fair abode, with price most meet,
Amenities decent, service neat,
Location, too, doth please,
O'erall, a good value, 'tis seen.

Fourth or fifth time, we've stayed here,
Rooms clean, comfort doth bring cheer,
Food selection, diverse,
From McDonald's to French, so fine.

Casino floor, a bit small, smoky,
But for lounging, quite okay,
Spa, small, prices reasonable,
Nearby malls, a short way.

Showers, high pressure, not nice,
TV, on recent trip, did not entice,
But still, we stayed, content,
And saved cash, to indulge, bent.

Nicer places, on the strip,
Twice the cost, a fool's grip,
Here, we stay, satisfied,
And save funds, for fun, unrip."

"Tucked away, hard to see, near Ella's Deli so fine,
But worth a visit, if thou seek'st a meal divine.
Gyros and kebabs, they do serve, with donuts galore,
And cookies, homemade baklava, they do store.

Sandwiches, oh so tasty, with fries seasoned just right,
Vegetarian options, kahbi or falafel, a delight.
Beverages, plenty to choose, quenching thirst with glee,
A hidden gem, this eatery, wait and see.

Though the location may not be, the best of all,
It's worth a stop, give it a try, standing tall.
So, venture forth, and taste, the flavors they impart,
For in this humble place, thou shalt find a culinary art."

"When first this place did open, 'twas good, I'd give it five stars, upon my word! Now, 'tis but mediocre, yet still we went, for my father doth enjoy it, yea, verily. 
We began with grilled artichoke, usually a tasty treat, but alas, this time 'twas hard and lacking in flavor, perhaps because artichokes be out of season, who knows? The aioli, however, did please my taste buds. 
The prime rib, though tender and well-flavored, was naught but ordinary, and the portions, alack! did shrink with each visit. A baked potato, plain and simple, did accompany it, and no sweet treat did we partake. 
Still, I reckon we shall return, for my father doth hold this place in high esteem."

Barneys is a chill spot, not too flashy. Good place to have a few drinks, no fuss. Second floor's my jam, bartender's on point. Roof's nice too, but smokers ruin it for me. Beer's poured bottom up, funky fresh. Lobster game's a blast when you're feeling frisky. Solid 3.5 stars.

My spouse, fair maiden, didst venture forth
Upon a Monday eve, with friends in tow,
To yonder zoo, where creatures great and small
Didst roam and frolic, or so she didst suppose.

But lo, the place didst not meet her expectations,
For though 'twas neat, the beasts were fewer than she'd hoped.
And, alack, the entrance fee didst seem quite steep,
Ten silver pieces for locals, oh how they didst gape!

And, cruel fate, the sun didst beat down fiercely,
A hundred degrees, and not a drop of water nigh.
The fountains, all, didst bear the mark of "out of order",
A danger, indeed, for visitors, in sooth.

They shouldst provide, at all times, water free,
For such a lack, a hazard doth it be.

"Hark! Good sirs and madams, gather 'round,
For here at UNLV, a deal most profound,
Five tacos, two sides, a drink, all for a fiver,
A feast fit for a king, nay, a scholar, a sage, a wizard!

The tacos, traditional street fare, small but full of cheer,
With meat aplenty, no skimping, no fear,
A place to meet with friends, share a bucket of ale,
And laugh and chat, with nary a care or a frown,

Order at the counter, wait for thy number to be called,
And savor each bite, with joy unconfined, unbounded,
Live music or DJ, on certain eves, a Latin theme,
A festive atmosphere, a jolly good time, 'tis seen!"

"First Friday's got me feelin' torn. Love community events, especially art walks. But this one's missin' somethin'. Should be great, it's in my backyard, but it don't deliver. 

Galleries are lackin', vendors just tryna make a buck. Kids everywhere, grungy ones causin' trouble. Food stalls are decent in summer, but winter's a bust. 

Prob'ly still go back, but early, before it gets wild."

"Methought the surroundings were most fair,
And staff, their courtesy did abound.
The victuals, alas, did not quite meet
The price, which left me in a sour mood.

But still, I must confess, the place
Did have a certain je ne sais quoi,
A charm that did my senses please,
And made my visit there most enjoyable."

"Went to TMI for grub the other night. Toast was the highlight, good bread, even if it was a bit crusty. Mac and cheese was a letdown, oily and flavorless. Other folks liked their sammies and salads, though. Nice joint, but too hot, loud, and the food was just alright. Won't be back soon."

"Marry, I chanced upon a wondrous sight,
A cache of irrigation supplies most bright.
As one who doth tend the garden with great care,
I do confess, my needs for such things are rare.
Emitters, hose, and connectors galore,
They had them all, and at a price so poor.
'Twas a veritable treasure trove, I swear,
And I, a humble gardener, didst declare,
My filthy habit, it doth seem, doth thrive,
Thanks to this find, my dear, my heart doth strive."

"Good spot. Family-style grub, just how I like it. Some dishes worked, others didn't. Eggplant and goat cheese, too much cheese, not enough eggplant. Egg and potato, heavy on the spuds. Filet mignon and Thai beef salad, solid choices. Worth a shot, but unlikely to return."

"Hark! My dearest wife and I, we had not been
To this place, once known as Cafe Del Sol,
Since time immemorial, it seems.
A Groupon we had purchased, a month agone,
Didst prompt our visit, 'twas a curious case.
The main dining room, grand and spacious,
And a smaller room, apart, yet adjacent,
A red-headed stepchild, with naught to do
But hold its own, in solitude.
We arrived at happy hour's end, my dear,
And thou didst order Sangria, a drink most fair.
I, a glass of Tempranillo, didst choose,
Alas, 'twas poor, and left me in a souse.
Another glass of wine, its name now lost,
Didst please me well, and made my spirit boast.
Thou didst order cola, pineapple, and short ribs,
Jalapeno cream corn, a chile corn casserole,
The sides were good, the corn, a tad dry,
The short ribs, great, without that cheap lie.
The sauce, too thick, yet not a major flaw,
My dearest wife, her grilled shrimp didst raw.
With avocado, mango sauce, an appetizer,
And empanadas, a dish most curious,
She loved her food, I must confess,
Yet empanadas, not to my liking, alas.
The shrimp, quite good, a saving grace,
In conclusion, 'tis a decent place,
Another option, in this fair town,
Yet would I choose to go again? Fie upon it!"
"Dive bar, off the strip. Friday night, empty. Free beers, courtesy of Fremont Street. Loud, obnoxious bartenders, but fun. Watch out for the shot scams. Your bill's gonna skyrocket."

"Stayed at Hotel Monte Carlo Las Vegas a few times, but it's time to move on. Place is showing its age, especially compared to newer hotels. Food at the main cafe and buffet is just okay. But, gotta give 'em credit, they've got a good deal going on - concierge puts guests on the VIP list for free entry into Haze and other nearby clubs. That's a nice touch. If you're looking for deals and decent rooms, it's worth checking out."

"Hark! I've dined at two locations of this establishment,
On Sunset and on Rainbow, both served me well,
The steak and eggs, a hearty breakfast indeed,
And happy hour, with drafts and appetizers, a swell.

Thus, I give these two places an "A" with ease,
For their fare and service, most excellent, if you please.
But alas, their reward card, a joke, I do declare,
They changed the levels, so now it's hard to get there.

Years it would take, to earn a mere $10 credit,
No warning given, no thought to past merit.
So on this score, an "F" they must receive,
A poor showing, indeed, and quite uncivil.

Thus, three stars, a middling grade, I do impart,
'Twixt "A" and "F", a mediocre mark, a fair start."

"Methinks 'twas passable fare, my dear. A bit perplexing, the ordering system did seem, yet, clever lass that I be, I didst unravel its mysteries with ease. In quest of savory burger, my heart didst yearn, and lo! I chanced upon a dish most meet, just as I had desired. Alas, a mite of charm didst it lack, to make it truly memorable, I do confess."

"Resort restaurant. Food ambitious, prices steep. Chicken, solid choice. Service top-notch. Table beside us, smoke fest. Already done, sat outside. Pricey for what you get. Good grub, resort pricing. Won't return. Server, pleasant. 3 stars, fair."

"Few blocks make much difference going east. Love me some Lao Laan, never had it before Madison. Service and menu recs ain't the same, authenticity lacking. Menu's smaller, dining room bigger, good for grooving, but Willy's still the best bet for curry east of the capitol."

"Aye, 'twas a good burger indeed, yet pricey, I must confess. Nearby, I toil, and hoped for a midday meal, alack! But lo, they be not open at that hour, so I didst depart, dismayed. The staff, kind and courteous, served with grace, yet naught but dinner, they do provide, and thus, my visits, shall be rare."

"Menu's still the same as it has been for six years now. In Montreal, you know. But that radish oyster dish, damn good. Can't get enough of it. Worth every penny of those twelve bucks for four oysters. Rest of the menu? Ordinary, overpriced."

"Picked up a new laptop charger, needed the Lion OSX upgrade too. Easy peasy, right? Wrong. On Leopard, gotta buy two upgrades to get to Lion. What the hell, Apple? Can't even find the Leopard to Snow Leopard upgrade at the damn store. Ended up ordering it online, waiting like a fool. Stupidity aside, the place was clean, employee was decent. That's something, I guess."

"Good grub at a fair price. That's what you'll get here. No frills, just solid eats. Service is friendly, food's decent, and the cost won't break the bank. Don't let the three stars throw you off. It's a damn good spot for a satisfying meal."

"Decent grub, I had the 'Sin City' burger. Liked it plenty. Wife had a classic, don't know what was on it, but she enjoyed it. Sweet potato fries, not too keen on 'em. Seasoning wasn't my cup of tea. Regular fries, just alright. All in all, not bad. Better than most fast food joints."
"Kid-friendly, decent price. Staff's friendly too. Slices are edible, not the best taste though. Limited sweets and greens."

"Sweet tooth? Look no further. Old-fashioned ice cream joint in old town, pink decor and all. Friend and I stopped by for the buster brownie sundae - sweet, but worth it. They serve food too, but stick to the sweets."
"Wings good. Sauces good. Service hit or miss. Waffle fries overcooked. Don't believe the hype."

"Plate of food in front of me, huge, makes me squirm. Wanted chile rellenos, not the super-sized plate. Restaurants nowadays, portion control nonexistent. Friend could've shared, didn't know, no regrets. Vegas, table on Friday night, no wait, no reservation. Service attentive, bill reasonable. Mojito, tasty."

"PC, a Charlotte classic due for a refresh. Good grub, but consistency's a concern. Atmosphere's stale, stuck in the past. Still, worth a trip - especially when the weather's fine and you can snag a spot on the sweet patio. Salads are top-notch."

"Slipped in for a drink before dinner. Place was rowdy, real rowdy. People hollerin' at the TVs, birthday crews ragin', music blastin'. Gin joint, mostly. Beer menu's lackin', but their gin game's strong. Tried the Ungava with maple syrup, and damn, it was good. Not usually a gin guy, but that maple syrup's magic. Pricey, though. Twenty bucks for a beer and cocktail? No way, José. Service was top-notch, though. Waitress hustlin' between them big ol' parties, still took care of us quick as can be."

"Central Library's got nothing on this place. This is where they keep the good stuff - all the rare books. You'll need to get a pass from the registration desk, but it's worth it if you're looking for something specific. If not, then it's a bit of a hassle just to read a book. But hey, your call."

"A fair sports bar, perchance? My sire didst suggest,
'Twas one of those new, merry places, he didst profess.

The portabella mushrooms, stuffed and baked,
Didst please mine taste, though rich, they didst partake.
Carnitas libre pizza, too, didst delight,
But oh, the richness! Taste thy arteries take flight.

Pollotate pizza, alas, didst fail to impress,
Bland, dry, and lacking zest, didst leave me in distress.
Yet, forgetful cooks didst omit onions, by chance,
Which may, in truth, improve the dish, in some dance.

Kind servers, gracious, didst make amends,
And compensated well, their faults, didst mend.
A plethora of TVs, a bar most stocked,
For fans of sport, a haven, this place hath wrought.

Yet, for myself, such calories, I do not crave,
Unless the fare be special, in some high wave.
This place, alas, doth not reach such heights, I fear,
So, to my mind, not worth the caloric spear."

"Hark! A tale of lunchtime adventure, dear friends!

After a morning spent in yogic pursuits, I chanced upon a place called TDP, nestled within the bustling hub of Union. 'Twas a curious sight, for half the shops lay open, while the others slumbered still.

The establishment itself, I must confess, did charm mine eyes. The tables, neat and tidy, beckoned me to sit and partake of their offerings. The outdoor seating, a pleasant surprise, did invite me to bask in the sun's warm rays. And the bar, though small, did sparkle with promise.

The staff, kind and courteous, did attend to mine needs with haste. My sandwich, drenched in olive oil, did tantalize mine taste buds. The bread, fresh and soft, did complement the savory filling well.

Yet, alas! The price, dear friends, did stir within me a sense of dismay. Nine silver coins for a simple Caprese sandwich? Methinks 'tis a steep price to pay. And the meatball sandwich, lacking in sauce, did leave me feeling somewhat unsatisfied. The chicken salad sandwich, though visually appealing, did seem a trifle small for the cost.

Verily, I say unto thee, I shall return anon, to partake of their wares no more. But, I shall cherish the memories of that day, and the sweet scents that did fill mine nostrils. Forsooth, a bottle of their finest olive oil shall be mine prize, and a token of our fleeting encounter."

Jersey Mike's didn't knock me off my feet, but it's a tight ship. Efficient, friendly, and clean. Menu's a bit tricky for a newbie, but I managed. Place was hopping at lunchtime. Mini sub's a decent size, regular's a behemoth. Club had plenty of meat. Sub rolls were alright, hard to tell apart. Cups are cool, each one's got a story. Fundraising for good causes? Hope so. Might just be branding. I'll be back, craving something spicy next time.

"Methinks 'twas a fortuitous day indeed, fair friends, when we didst stumble upon yon establishment, Los 7 Compadres. Forsooth, their menu didst boast a plethora of combination platters, a veritable cornucopia of culinary delights, all for a mere seven golden coins! My dearest wife and I, in our hunger and delight, didst order two such platters, that we might share and savor each dish. And thus, we didst embark upon a gastronomical journey, a true feast for the senses.

"First, we didst sample the chicken enchilada, a tender, juicy morsel, swathed in a rich, velvety sauce. Next, we didst add rice, and then beans, and thus, a new creation was born! The sour cream and guacamole, too, didst make their mark, each adding its unique flavor to the mix. And so, we didst continue, combining and recombining, until our taste buds didst dance with joy.

"And thus, we didst play this game again, with the burrito, the cheese enchilada, the tamale, the beef enchilada, the bean enchilada, and more! Each dish, a masterpiece, a symphony of flavors, a true delight. The tamales, alack, didst fall short, a tad dry, with naught but jalapeno's spice to savor. Yet, the rest, a true culinary triumph!

"In conclusion, my friends, Los 7 Compadres, doth earn three and a half stars from mine own pen. A worthy venture, indeed, and one that shall draw us back again, anon!"

"Hark! This place doth puzzle me, and I shall not keep the ill tidings till the end. Forsooth, they do take pride in allowing, yea, even encouraging, the foul habit of smoking. 'Tis strange, for their ale selection is most generous, and their victuals, too, are of high quality. Pizzas, sandwiches, and appetizers abound. But, alack! Who wishes to return home reeking of the foulest ashtray? Methinks 'twould be best if they did join the rest of us in this, the twenty-first century."

"Hark! Good sir, what tidings bring thee here?
A craving for V-food, perchance? Fear not,
For in this fair city, downtown's the place,
Where culinary delights doth abound and grace.

At First and Adams, a restaurant doth lie,
With open kitchen, a wondrous sight to see.
Their take-out doth please, with speedy service too,
But, alas, the taste, not quite as sweet as true.

The prices, dear sir, do reflect the place,
A trifle steep, yet still a bargain, in its grace.
For thirty bucks, a meal for two doth cost,
Yet, at divier joints, the price doth drop, no boast.

Still, I shall support them, in times of need,
For take-out or lunch, their fare doth feed.
But, if authentic Vietnamese food doth crave,
To the avenues, I shall flee, their dives to save.

Alas, the bahn mi, they didst lack, that day,
Yet, the buhn dice, a standard dish, did play.
Egg rolls, good sir, with veggies filled,
But, alack, the spring rolls, shrimp, didst lack, and still.

The omelette, an acquired taste, doth say,
And thus, I leave it, with naught else to sway."

"Chinatown in Montreal's small, but reliable for good, cheap eats. Rice is a must for my mom, always. Their roast pork/duck over rice is solid. Beef pan fried noodles? Not so much. Wonton noodle soup's decent, though. General Tso's chicken? Pretty good. Service is hit or miss, depending on the waiter. If they speak English well, it's good. Otherwise, frustrating. Food comes out quick, so if you're starving, it's a good spot. Bubble tea's alright, but not great. They get props for the baby bok choy and huge portions."

"Hark, what news is this? A restaurant once grand,
Now fallen to three stars, its glory lost.
I chanced upon the scene, a sight most foul,
Two roaches roamed the floor, unchecked and bold.
I rose and crushed one, as if in sport,
But none took note, their minds elsewhere employed.
A staff member slew the other, with no show,
As if such pests were common, naught to know.

The waiter, full of words and empty cheer,
Did prattle on, as if we cared to hear.
His voice, like nails on glass, did grate and scrape,
And made us wish for silence, or a gentle breeze to shape.

The owner, too, we met, a man of wine and mirth,
Who ruled the patio, with laughter and with girth.
But in his eyes, a glint of strife did gleam,
As if he ruled with iron hand, his will supreme.

The food, still fair, yet not as once it was,
A shadow of its former self, alas.
We sought alternatives, new delights to find,
For such a place, with pests and noise entwined, did leave us blind."

"Twenty-nine ninety-nine, thirty-two forty-two with tax, too rich for my blood. Lot of grub, sure, but not worth the scratch compared to some swanky joints.

Saturday morning, ten fifteen, mimosas flowed like water. Had me two, they hit the spot. Breakfast and lunch, they got 'em both, had a bit of each. Yeah, brunch, you know.

Nothin' blew my skirt up, but it was all good eats. Not some massive spread, but enough to fill you up.

Might go back, you know, if I'm 1) hammered, 2) jonesin' for AYCE, 3) stranded, 4) held hostage, or 5) drunk again. That's about it."

"Mexican and Chinese, why not? Interesting menu. Jade Red Chicken, just as good as Orange or General Tso's. Wide variety, good food, especially if you like spicy. 

One issue, cleanliness. Low budget decor, uncomfortable seating, weathered ceilings, messy. Not a big deal. But restrooms were disgusting, eating area dirty, trash overflowing. Busy, but no excuse for men's restroom. Looked like a truck stop after a long weekend. Doors and walls filthy, handprints everywhere. Most tables dirty, only one trash bin not full. Glad I didn't use the restroom until after I ate. 

If it were mine, I'd invest in some maintenance. Better tables and chairs wouldn't hurt either. Close to clean, four stars easy."

In haste, I entered, snatching victuals for night's repast.
This shop, ne'er had I trodden, till this day, alas!
'Tis passable, I reckon, though the fruits and veggies be not prime,
Yet in a pinch, they'll serve, being nigh my humble dome.
Safeway, methinks, doth boast finer fare,
For fruits, veggies, and perchance meats, beyond compare.
The prices, middling, with some deals, to be sure,
But naught that doth make this place most singular, I do confess.

"First visit was a bust. Food didn't live up to the hype. Artichoke appetizer was a disappointment, and my burger was bland. Wife's steak was mediocre, and she got sick afterwards. Server, Cassie, was top-notch though. Friendly and attentive. Manager reached out, offering a coupon. Gave the place a second chance, but food needs to step up its game."

"Sunday arvo, empty joint. Friend raved about it, but service was too quick - must've been pre-cooked. Chicken full of bones, pork like rock. Cubans like it rough? 

Parking's round back. Lock up tight, don't walk alone. 

Might go back, try somethin' else. Gave 'em three stars for friendly service, bilingualism, no food poisoning."

"This joint closed? Or just getting a facelift?\n\nBeen here a few times for lunch, and gotta say, the barbacoa torta's my jam. Nothing else on the menu's all that special. Had the breakfast burrito once...potatoes overpowered the chorizo. Pricey too."

"Fare was inventive, flavors did please.
Appetizers, a fair price did seize.
But alas, main courses did falter,
Portions small, the price did alter.
Bread, a tad dry, yet still a delight,
With wine, a varied selection in sight.
In Chandler's sun, a decent find,
Though pricey, for dinner, a mind not inclined.
I'd return for apps and vino, no doubt,
But for now, their fate, a lingering thought."

"Cocktails most fine, a joy to behold,
But alas, not all bartenders do them justice, so bold.
Mojitos, oh how they delight,
A reasonable price, a pleasant sight.
The decor, quite nice, a place to relax,
The crowd, a mix, but all in good spirits, perchance.
Music, a gentle melody, doth please the ear,
A brunch, with lobster omelette, did I hold dear.
Alas, too many flavors, my taste did confound,
But others, I'm sure, would find it most profound.
Guava mimosa, a drink of the gods,
But alas, not on this day, did it please my nods."

"Upgrading to three stars due to top-notch service. Server-to-guest ratio was near one-to-one, can't complain about that. Place isn't doing too well, though. Prices are steep and portions are small. You get what you pay for, but it's still a bit much. Burgers, skewers, sandwiches, and salads run around ten bucks each. Pizzas cost between ten and fifteen. A la carte menu, and you only get a few skewers for your entree. Appetizers are ten dollars too. Desserts are seven, plus an extra dollar for ice cream. Not bad, but not worth it either. Their burgers are better than The Grind's, at least they don't fall apart. Fries were decent, five bucks. Pork skewers were meh. Dorito potato skins? Meh. Cupcake was alright, but the chocolate was a tad grainy. Small portion too. Won't be back for anything but happy hour, and that's just for the burgers."

"In verdant Verdun, a culinary gem doth lie,
Through friendship's grapevine, we did hear its cry.
Skepticism aside, we ventured forth to try,
And Parisa's fare did our taste buds surprise and fly.
